awd_titl_txt: Darwinism Old and New: Research on the History of Evolutionary Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, which is supported by NSF's Science, Technology, and Society Program, focuses on a particular period in the history of evolutionary biology. It will research a contentious period for evolutionary biology, from the 1880s through the 1930s?roughly from the death of Charles Darwin to the eve of the "modern evolutionary synthesis," when a consensus of sorts was reached on many of the points of contention. It will be conducted in various European and American archives and libraries. The eventual goal is to produce a scholarly monograph and a series of preliminary articles.

The planned publications will focus on two generations of biologists in Germany and Austria (foremost among them Ernst Haeckel, Richard Semon, Paul Kammerer, and Ludwig Plate), their competition with each other and with scientists in Britain and the U.S. to define "Darwinism" and modernize it in response to twentieth-century challenges. 

Among the challenges they faced were discerning the nature and causes of variation, reconciling the rule of law in nature with the unpredictability of evolutionary change, responding to the increasing prestige and authority of experimentation over the evolutionist's traditional comparative methods. The period includes the advent of genetics, the chromosome theory, and new ways of conceptualizing heredity and variation. It also includes the eugenics movement and rising expectations for biologists to address social problems, as well as global and national political changes in the wake of the First World War.

This project will contribute to the broadening scope of the historical literature on Darwinism by filling out the international and inter-generational picture, revising standard views of the politics of German biology, and especially by making new and stronger connections between nineteenth- and twentieth-century Darwinian thought. It will also be of interest to biologists and philosophers working on "evo-devo," the new evolutionary developmental biology, to see how the relationships among evolution, development, and heredity have been defined and debated before. In addition, many issues addressed by this research have been in the public eye in twenty-first-century America, and the project should have an impact on science teaching and public understanding of evolution and its political, religious and moral interpretations.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the history of evolutionary biology in the decades after the death of Charles Darwin in 1882. It was a period of intense competition between schools of evolutionary thought that differed in their thinking about the nature and causes of variation, how heredity worked, and the relative importance of natural selection as an agent of change. The possibilities could hardly be narrowed down until at least the 1930s, when the consensus known as the "modern evolutionary synthesis" emerged.

The focus here was on evolutionary theorists in Germany and Austria, with special attention to their views on the randomness (as opposed to the predictability, purposefulness, or directedness) of variation. The main subjects of investigation were Ernst Haeckel and several younger members (Richard Semon, Ludwig Plate, and Paul Kammerer) of his "old school" of Darwinism. They insisted on interpreting variations as unconscious and un-purposive responses by the organism to environmental forces. The process allowed individual organisms to acquire new characteristics, which were presumed to be heritable under at least some circumstances. This had certain ideological advantages for Haeckel and his school. It allowed them to argue that evolution was flexible and creative, but had no need---and provided no evidence---for divine intervention. It also raised questions (especially for Kammerer) about the effectiveness of eugenics programs in the absence of environmental and educational reforms. On the other hand, it proved difficult to reconcile the inheritance of acquired characteristics with new findings in genetics after 1900, and difficult to provide experimental evidence for it.

This investigation made use of newly available source material on early genetics to shed light on these issues and to reveal how individual members of the old school interacted with leading geneticists, tried to deal with advances in the study of heredity, and responded to various other twentieth-century challenges. It also suggests---contrary to standard assumptions about Germany biology---that they were not disconnected from the international mainstream and that some of their views were still influential at the time of the modern synthesis.

Theses findings are important for several academic disciplines. For specialists on the history of biology, they bring out the diversity of approaches to evolution and heredity and contribute to the international and intergenerational picture of the development of Darwinism. They undermine the commonly accepted dichotomy between “Lamarckism” and neo-Darwinism and revises standard views of the period and especially of German Darwinism. They show that Darwin was not misunderstood or “eclipsed” before the modern synthesis, as is often claimed, but rather that a variety of possible interpretations of his work were explored and turned to competing scientific and social purposes. Finally, they suggest new ways of looking at twentieth-century evolutionary biology as a broadly based synthesis of earlier approaches.

This research will have an impact not only on the history of biology, but on modern German history, public understanding of evolution and its social and political implications, and undergraduate instruction. In German history, it challenges commonly held assumptions about the political and humanistic implications of Darwinism, especially the idea that Haeckel put German biologists on an aberrant path to Nazi racial ideology. Instead, this study proposes a better-contextualized view of nineteenth-century Germany and the place of German biology in international comparison. Other issues addressed by this research are much in the public eye in twenty-first-century America, for example in controversies over evolution and its relationship to religion and moral values.
